Menkominfo akan Kebut RUU Perlindungan Data Pribadi
05 Nov 2019, 14:08 by Budiarti Utami Putri, Syailendra Persada
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Menteri Komunikasi dan Informatika Johnny G. Plate mengatakan Rancangan Undang-undang Perlindungan Data Pribadi akan kembali dibahas bersama Dewan Perwakilan Rakyat periode 2020-2024. Dia mengatakan RUU ini juga akan masuk program legislasi nasional (Prolegnas) prioritas 2020.
"Tentu perlu menempatkannya di dalam prolegnas prioritas DPR RI, dan Prolegnas prioritas 2020 dan Prolegnas 2020-2024," kata Johnny di Kompleks Parlemen, Senayan, Jakarta, Selasa, 5 November 2019.
Menurut Johnny, pembahasan RUU Perlindungan Data Pribadi ini tak terlepas dari arahan Presiden Joko Widodo atau Jokowi. Kata dia, Jokowi mengingatkannya ihwal kedaulatan data ini.
Dia mengatakan saat ini data-data termasuk data pribadi warga negara tersebar di pelbagai aturan dan undang-undang.
"Sangat sektoral dan parsial. Kami inginkan untuk melakukan kompilasi di dalam satu undang-undang yang disebut undang-undang perlindungan data pribadi ini," ujarnya.
Soal kedaulatan data ini pernah diungkapkan Jokowi saat pidato kenegaraan pada 16 Agustus 2019 di hadapan anggota DPR dan Dewan Perwakilan Daerah. Jokowi kala itu bahkan menyebut data lebih berharga dari minyak.
"Kita harus siaga menghadapi ancaman kejahatan siber termasuk kejahatan penyalahgunaan data. Data adalah jenis kekayaan baru bangsa kita, kini data lebih berharga dari minyak," kata Jokowi di Jakarta, Jumat, 16 Agustus 2019.
Kutipan Jokowi soal data lebih berharga dari minyak ini mirip dengan pernyataan Brittany Kaiser, bekas pegawai Cambridge Analytica yang diwawancara untuk film dokumenter Netflix The Great Hack.
Film dokumenter The Great Hack ini mengangkat soal bagaimana Cambridge Analytica, perusahaan analis data asal Inggris, yang diduga memanfaatkan data pengguna Facebook untuk kampanye Presiden Amerika Serika Donald Trump.
Brittany Kaiser, bekas karyawati di sana, angkat bicara karena jengah dengan perusahaan yang diduga menyalahgunakan data. Dalam wawancara film itu di Thailand, ia berkata, "Perusahaan paling kaya kebanyakan perusahaan teknologi. Google, Facebook, Amazon, Tesla. alasan mereka menjadi perusahaan paling kuat di dunia karena nilai sebuah data melebihi harga minyak. Data adalah aset paling berharga di dunia."

The Minister of Communication and Information will speed up the Personal Data Protection Bill
05 Nov 2019, 14:08 by Budiarti Utami Putri, Syailendra Persada
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Communication and Information Minister Johnny G. Plate said that the Draft of Personal Data Protection Act will be discussed again with the House of Representatives for the period 2020-2024. He said the bill would also be included in the 2020 priority national legislation program (Prolegnas).
"Of course it is necessary to place it in the priority process of the DPR RI, and the priority process of 2020 and Prolegnas 2020-2024," Johnny said at the Parliament Complex, Senayan, Jakarta, Tuesday, 5 November 2019.
According to Johnny, the discussion of the Personal Data Protection Bill is inseparable from the direction of President Joko Widodo or Jokowi. He said, Jokowi reminded him about the sovereignty of this data.
He said that currently data including personal data of citizens are scattered in various rules and laws.
"It is sectoral and partial. We want to compile it in a law called the personal data protection law," he said.
The issue of sovereignty of this data was ever revealed by Jokowi during a state address on August 16, 2019 in the presence of members of the DPR and the Regional Representative Council. At that time Jokowi mentioned that the data was more valuable than oil.
"We must be prepared to face the threat of cyber crime including data misuse. Data is a new type of wealth of our nation, now data is more valuable than oil," Jokowi said in Jakarta, Friday, August 16, 2019.
Jokowi's quote about data more valuable than oil is similar to the statement of Brittany Kaiser, a former employee of Cambridge Analytica who was interviewed for the Netflix documentary The Great Hack.
The documentary The Great Hack raises the question of how Cambridge Analytica, a British data analyst company, allegedly used Facebook user data for the US President Donald Trump campaign.
Brittany Kaiser, a former employee there, spoke up because she was embarrassed by the company that was suspected of misusing data. In the film interview in Thailand, he said, "The richest companies are mostly technology companies. Google, Facebook, Amazon, Tesla. The reason they are the most powerful companies in the world is because the value of a data exceeds the price of oil. Data is the most valuable asset in the world. "
